moves.1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf: We are still well within theory. This is a thematic move in the Sicilian Dragon. The rook eyes the knight on c3 with x-ray vision, prepared to possibly sacrifice itself there eventually.
moves.11. Bb3 Ne5: Obviously, it's not time to do so yet. Just because a sacrifice is thematic and possible does not mean that it should be played automatically. Both sides have signalled their intentions here - to go straight for each other's kings!
moves.12. h4 h5: Black cannot allow White's pawn to go to h5.
moves.13. Bg5 Rc5 14. g4 hxg4 15. f4 Nc4 16. Q: This move, which is still not a new move, works for tactical reasons, as we shall see...
moves.17. Ndxb5: Has White won a pawn for nothing?
moves.17... Nxb2: Black's dragon bishop breathes fire down the long diagonal.
moves.18. Kxb2 Bxb5: The first new move according to the Gameknot database. 18...Nxe4 had been played twice previously.
moves.19. Nxb5 Nxe4+ 20. Kb1: I analyzed this game with Shredder, which concluded that 20.Kc1 would have been much better for White. The king is very vulnerable on b1 to mates on b2.
moves.20... Nf2: Material isn't the most important consideration here, but it makes sense to remove one of the rooks, as the knight was threatened anyway.
moves.21. Qe2 Nxd1: I think I probably should have captured the rook on h1 instead.
moves.22. Rxd1 Qa5 23. a4 Rb8: 23...Rxb5 followed by Qc3 would have been much better.
